School of Chemical Engineering and Technology, Hebei University of Technology Tianjin 300131 China Piperidine (PIP) is an important nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compound used extensively in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and rubber additives. Conventional synthesis routes often require energy-intensive conditions or noble metal catalysts, posing environmental and economic challenges. This work presents a sustainable chemical process for PIP production, starting from biomass-derived δ-valerolactone. The key reductive amination step employs a bimetallic Ni-Co core-shell catalyst (L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2), prepared via a continuous-flow method. Under optimized conditions, a 100 % conversion of 4-cyanobutanal (4-CB) was achieved with 63.8 % selectivity for PIP. Catalyst synergy between Ni and Co enhanced activity while reducing reliance on noble metals. This study demonstrates a scalable strategy for sustainable PIP production, aligning with green chemistry principles by employing renewable feedstocks, minimizing waste, and achieving high efficiency under mild conditions. Graphical Abstract Keywords Biomass-derived δ-valerolactod Ni-Co core-shell catalys Piperidine Sustainable catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Piperidine (PIP), an essential nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compound, has diverse applications across numerous industries. It is used as a solvent in organic synthesis, an olefin polymerization catalyst, and an accelerator in synthetic resin and rubber production. In the pharmaceutical sector, PIP serves as a crucial intermediate in synthesizing analgesics, anti-allergic drugs, and local anesthetics [1]. In the agrochemical industry, PIP plays a key role in the synthesis of insecticides and fungicides, such as phenazopyridine. Additionally, PIP is widely employed in producing specialty chemicals and polymers. The main routes for PIP synthesis include pyridine hydrogenation, dehydration cyclization of 5-amino-1-pentanol, and hydrogenation-deoxygenation of valerolactam, among which pyridine hydrogenation is predominantly used in industrial production. However, all these methods exhibit inherent limitations. Pyridine hydrogenation remains the most widely adopted method for industrial PIP production due to its synthetic simplicity. Kustov et al.[2] developed a γ-Al₂O₃-supported bimetallic Pd-Ag catalyst that efficiently catalyzes pyridine hydrogenation under mild conditions (60 °C, 70 atm H₂), achieving high PIP yields. However, the reliance on precious metals significantly raises production costs, hampering large-scale applications. In contrast, the synthesis of piperidines by dehydration and cyclisation of 5-amino-1-pentanol uses non-precious metal catalysts, whereas the synthesis of piperidines from biomass material relies on precious metal catalysts. Liu et al.[3] reported a one-pot method for the rapid synthesis of piperidines from biomass-derived tetrahydrofurfurylamine by selective hydrogenolysis of tetrahydrofurfurylamine to 5-amino-1-pentanol intermediates in aqueous solution, followed by intramolecular amination over a supported Rh-ReOx catalyst. Rh-ReOx/SiO2 was highly efficient and stable in this reaction, which gave a yield of 91.5 % of piperidines at 200 °C and 2.0 MPa H2. Tsuchiya et al.[4] reported PIP synthesis via gas-phase dehydration of 5-amino-1-pentanol over metal oxides such as ZrO₂, TiO₂, SiO₂, and Al₂O₃. Although biomass materials aligned with green chemistry principles are utilized, the high cost of catalysts remains a significant challenge. Meanwhile, catalytic reactions employing non-noble metals face issues such as rapid catalyst deactivation, limiting their scalability and industrial feasibility. Similarly, the hydrogenation-deoxygenation of valerolactam offers a greener route by avoiding toxic intermediates. Hirosawa et al.[5] demonstrated that although a Rh₆(CO)₁₆-Re₂(CO)₁₀ bimetallic catalyst achieved a 100 % valerolactam conversion and 75 % PIP yield, its reliance on precious metals and the reduced catalyst stability during the deoxygenation step remain significant drawbacks. These limitations highlight the urgent need for a cost-effective, environmentally friendly, and milder approach to PIP synthesis. Developing a sustainable and economical PIP synthesis method under mild conditions is of great significance. Large-scale production of furfural from biomass feedstocks, such as corn cobs and agricultural by-products, has already been established. In addition, significant progress has been made in the synthesis of δ-valerolactone (δ-VL) from furfural and the production of aliphatic lactones from biomass-derived intermediates, offering a renewable alternative to reduce dependence on fossil fuels [6–11]. This makes δ-valerolactone a promising precursor for downstream products. In this study, we propose a novel green synthetic route for PIP using δ-valerolactone, a biomass-derived compound. The process involves two catalytic amination steps: δ-valerolactone is first aminated to 5-hydroxypentanenitrile (5-HPN), which is then oxidized to 4-cyanobutanal (4-CB), followed by reductive amination to yield PIP. A key innovation in this process is the use of a continuous-flow bimetallic core-shell catalyst, L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2, which demonstrates excellent catalytic activity and stability under mild conditions, significantly outperforming conventional methods that rely on harsh conditions and precious metal catalysts. This approach offers significant advantages. First, using δ-valerolactone from biomass as the raw material aligns with the principles of green chemistry, making the process more sustainable and environmentally friendly compared to petroleum-based feedstocks. Second, the continuous-flow bimetallic core-shell catalyst maximizes the synergistic effects of the Ni-Co alloy, reducing reliance on precious metals and lowering production costs. The catalyst shows excellent activity and selectivity while maintaining stability under low-pressure conditions. Lastly, mild reaction conditions minimize energy consumption, enhancing the overall environmental friendliness of the process. This approach not only provides a more economical and sustainable alternative to traditional PIP production methods but also aligns with global trends toward greener chemical processes. Given the abundant availability of raw materials, energy efficiency, and scalable catalyst performance, this method holds significant promise for industrial applications. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and reagents All reagents were analytical grade and used as received without further purification. δ-valerolactone was purchased from Shanghai Bide Pharmaceutical Technology Company. Metal nitrates and reagents for catalyst preparation were purchased from Tianjin Fuchen Chemical Reagent Company. 4-hydroxy-2,2,6,6-tetramethylPIP-1-oxyl radical (4-OH-TEMPO) were provided via Jiangsu Bosite Chemical Technology Company. Ammonia with a purity of 99 % was purchased from Tianjin Liufang High Tech Company. 2.2 Catalyst preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of Lv-meso-NixMy@Al2O3-z via continuous method As shown in Fig. 1, a total of 20.2 g of Ni(NO₃)₂·6H₂O, 8.7 g of Co(NO₃)₂·6H₂O, and 0.187 g of Al(NO₃)₃·9H₂O were dissolved in 500 mL of deionized water, forming solution A. Simultaneously, 4.0 g of NaOH and 10.6 g of Na₂CO₃ were dissolved in another 500 mL of deionized water to prepare solution B. Both solutions were introduced into a membrane dispersion microreactor at a uniform flow rate of 7.5 mL/min, facilitating the immediate co-precipitation of hydroxides at 70 °C. The resulting precipitate was separated by centrifugation and extensively washed with ethanol and distilled water until neutral. Afterward, it was dried at 100 °C for 10 hours, followed by calcination in air at 400 °C for 3 hours, giving rise to NiO-Co₂O₄-Al₂O₃ nanoparticles. These nanoparticles underwent a secondary alkali treatment in a solution (mH₂O: mNaOH = 6:1.6) with stirring at 70 °C for 2 hours, generating a porous structure in the metal core. Further washing of the particles with ethanol and distilled water was carried out until neutrality, and the product was dried to yield Lv-meso-NiO-Co₂O₄ nanoparticles. In this nomenclature, "meso" designates the creation of mesopores, while "L" reflects the continuous flow approach used for metal precursor preparation, and "v" denotes the flow rate applied during metal nitrate and precipitant solution mixing. To prepare the modified catalyst, 0.25 g of Lv-meso-NiO-Co₂O₄ nanoparticles was suspended in 50 mL of anhydrous ethanol and ultrasonicated for 30 minutes. Following this, 0.25 g of Al(NO₃)₃·9H₂O and 10 mL of ammonia were added, and the suspension was subjected to an additional 1 hour ultrasonication to ensure adequate precursor dispersion. The resulting precipitate was collected by centrifugation, repeatedly washed with ethanol and distilled water until reaching neutral pH, and then dried at 100 °C for 8 hours. Finally, the dried sample was reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere at 550 °C for 3 hours, with a heating ramp of 5 °C/min, producing the Lv-meso-NixMy@Al₂O₃-z catalyst. Herein, "M" represents the selected secondary metal species, "x" and "y" indicate the molar ratio of nickel to secondary metal, and "z" corresponds to the molar ratio of Al(NO₃)₃·9H₂O to (Nix+My) precursors. This tailored preparation approach ensures both the uniform distribution of metal components and the creation of a robust mesoporous structure with high catalytic activity. 2.2.2 Characterization of catalysts The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the samples were taken on Rigaku miniflex 600 X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation in the 2θ range of 5–90°, under a current of 40 mA and a tube voltage of 40 kV. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI spectrometer with an Al Kα X-ray excitation source. The Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) specific surface areas, total pore volumes and pore size distributions were measured via a pulsed N2 adsorption-desorption method at 77 K on a Mac Instruments ASAP 2460. The NH3-TPD analysis of the catalyst was performed using a Micromeritics AutoChem II 2920 chemical adsorption analyzer. The program was set as follows: the reduced catalyst sample was heated at a rate of 5 °C/min in a helium stream to 300 °C, and then purged for 60 min. The sample was then cooled to 100 °C and a 10 % NH3/He gas mixture (30–50 mL/min) was introduced and continued for 1 hour until saturation. Inert gas was introduced and purged at the adsorption temperature until the baseline stabilized, and finally, the sample was heated to 700 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min to record the NH3 desorption spectrum of the sample. H2-TPR analyses were carried out on a chemisorption instrument, model TP-5080B, from Syngenta. The test conditions were as follows: the catalyst samples were heated up to 150 °C and then cooled down to 50 °C under an inert gas atmosphere, after which the H2-Ar mixture was introduced and ramped up to 750 °C at a rate of 5 °C/min and the TPR signal data were recorded. The transmission electron micrographs (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron micrographs (TEM) and high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) images were taken on a FEI Talos F200X instrument operated at an accelerating voltage of 200 kV. For the TEM analysis, the samples were ultrasonically dispersed in anhydrous ethanol and then suspended on an ultrathin Cu grid-supported carbon foil. 2.3 Evaluation of the catalytic performance 2.3.1 Catalytic amination of δ-valerolactone to 5-HPN The catalytic amination of δ-valerolactone to 5-HPN was performed in a fixed-bed reactor. The TiO2-SiO2 catalyst was cut into cylindrical granules with a diameter and height of approximately 2.5 mm. A 25 mL volume of the prepared catalyst was loaded into the middle section of the reactor, with the reaction temperature closely monitored by a thermocouple centrally positioned within the catalyst bed. The reactor was preheated to 250–290 °C under a nitrogen purge. Upon reaching thermal equilibrium, liquid-phase δ-valerolactone was introduced at the top of the reactor using an advection pump, while gaseous ammonia was simultaneously fed via a mass flow controller. The combined feed vaporized within the reactor and passed through the catalyst bed with a residence time of 1–5 s. The reaction mixture was condensed and collected at the reactor's outlet for compositional analysis by gas chromatography. The crude 5-HPN was initially recrystallized to remove solid impurities and further purified by distillation, achieving a final purity exceeding 99 %. 2.3.2 Catalytic oxidation of 5-HPN to 4-CB A predefined amount of 5-HPN and 4-OH-TEMPO (catalyst) was dissolved in dichloromethane to form solution A. Solution B consisted of a mixture of KBr (co-catalyst), deionized water, and saturated sodium bicarbonate solution. Separately, a 1.8 M sodium hypochlorite solution (pH = 9.5) was prepared as solution C. As shown in Fig. 2, solutions A, B, and C were continuously introduced into the system via three independent feed pumps, each operating at precisely controlled flow rates. Solutions A and B were combined through the first three-way valve to enhance the dissolution and pre-reaction homogeneity, after which the resulting mixture was merged with solution C at the second three-way valve. The combined solution entered the Kiloflow microchannel reactor, where the reaction proceeded under well-regulated temperature conditions, with real-time monitoring via gas chromatography (GC) to ensure optimal conversion. Upon completion, the reactor effluent underwent phase separation through partition extraction. The organic layer was collected, sequentially washed three times with saturated sodium thiosulfate solution to quench any remaining oxidants and then with distilled water to remove inorganic impurities. Finally, the solvent was carefully removed under reduced pressure, yielding the target product 4-CB with a purity exceeding 95 %, making it suitable for direct use in subsequent reaction steps. 2.3.3 Catalytic reductive amination of 4-CB to PIP The catalytic amination of 4-cyanobutanal (4-CB) to synthesize piperidine (PIP) was performed in a high-pressure autoclave reactor equipped with magnetic stirring. A predefined and accurately measured quantity of 4-CB (>95 % purity) and 25 wt% aqueous ammonia solution were added to the reactor’s liner tube, followed by the introduction of 30 wt% of the pre-reduced catalyst. The reactor was securely sealed, and to ensure the complete removal of residual oxygen, it was purged with H2 via five repeated cycles. Subsequently, H2 was introduced and pressurized to 1.5–2.5 MPa. The reaction proceeded under controlled temperature conditions, maintained between 60 and 100 °C, with a constant stirring speed of 900 r/min for 3–9 hours. After completing the reaction, the reactor was allowed to cool naturally to room temperature. The reaction products were then examined using gas chromatography (GC) to determine their composition and purity. 2.3.4 Product analysis The reaction mixture was analyzed via a Shimadzu GC-2018 chromatograph equipped with an SH-624 capillary column (30 μm×0.53 mm×30 m) and a flame ionization detector (FID) using the internal standard method. The content of each liquid product was calculated using calibration curves, with N-methylpyrrolidone (NMP) as an internal standard for PIP. The GC temperature program was set to 120 °C for 10 min, and then the temperature was increased at 10 °C/min up to 250 °C. (1) 4 − CB conversion ( % ) = moles of 4 − cyanobutyraldehyde reacted moles 4 − cyanobutyraldehyde fed × 100 % (2) PIP selectivity ( % ) = moles of PIP generated moles of 4 − cyanobutyraldehyde reacted × 100 % (3) Yield ( % ) = conversion × selectivity × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic amination of δ-valerolactone to 5-HPN Building on our team's previous research on the two-step synthesis of adiponitrile from ε-caprolactone, the catalytic amination of δ-valerolactone was successfully carried out using a TiO₂-SiO₂ catalyst to produce 5-hydroxypentanenitrile (5-HPN), as shown in Scheme 1 [12]. The detailed procedures for catalyst preparation and the reaction process are described in the Experimental Section. By combining single-factor experiments with orthogonal experimental design, the optimal reaction conditions for 5-HPN synthesis were established as follows: 0.1 MPa NH₃, 300 °C, δ-valerolactone to NH₃ molar ratio of 1:11, and a residence time of 2 s. Under these conditions, δ-valerolactone achieved a conversion rate of 94 %, and the selectivity for 5-HPN was 75.6 %. 3.2 Catalytic oxidation of 5-HPN to 4-CB The oxidation of primary alcohols to aldehydes is a fundamental transformation in organic synthesis. Numerous TEMPO-based catalytic oxidation systems have been developed for this purpose [13–16]. As shown in Scheme 2, we employed the Anelli catalytic oxidation system (NaClO/4-OH-TEMPO) to convert 5-HPN to 4-CB. Optimal reaction conditions were established in a microchannel reactor as follows 5-hydroxyvaleronitrile to DCM molar ratio of 1:15, 4-OH-TEMPO at 2 mol% relative to the substrate, 1.2 equivalents of NaClO solution (1.8 M, pH 9.5), a reaction temperature of −5 °C, and a residence time of 2 s. Under these conditions, the yield of 4-CB reached 93.7 %. 3.3 Catalytic amination of 4-CB to PIP 3.3.1 Screening of catalysts As summarized in Table S1, the optimal preparation conditions and catalyst composition were determined through a systematic screening of primary and secondary metal components, metal ratios, shell type and thickness, the incorporation of pores in the core, calcination temperature, and reduction temperature. The most suitable catalyst identified was meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 ( Table S1 , Entry 26) [17–30]. However, the intermittent method previously used for metal nucleus preparation faced several significant limitations, including difficulties in controlling metal particle size, low material yields, excessive surfactant consumption, and considerable time costs. To address these challenges, a continuous preparation method employing a membrane-dispersed microreactor was developed. Optimization of this method focused on adjusting the precipitant-to-metal salt molar ratio, precipitant type, and the flow rates of the metal salt and precipitant solutions. Initially, Na₂CO₃ and NaOH (at a 1:1 molar ratio) were selected as precipitants, and the effect of the precipitant-to-metal salt molar ratio on catalyst performance was investigated under conditions of a total metal salt concentration of 0.2 mol/L and flow rates of 10 mL/min for both solutions. As shown in Fig. 3 (a), increasing the molar ratio from 1.5:1–2:1 improved the selectivity for PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine from 41.7 % and 7.2–48.3 % and 17.4 %, respectively. However, further increases in the molar ratio resulted in reduced selectivity for both products. Based on XRD analysis, this phenomenon is attributed to the smaller grain size of the catalyst at the optimized 2:1 molar ratio, which enhances catalytic performance by increasing the density of active sites. Consequently, a precipitant-to-metal salt molar ratio of 2:1 was selected as the optimal condition. After determining the optimal precipitant-to-metal salt molar ratio, the effect of precipitant type on catalyst performance was systematically studied. As shown in Fig. 3 (b), the use of NaOH or ammonia as precipitants resulted in suboptimal catalyst performance, with PIP selectivity of 40.1 % and 38.4 %, and 1,5-pentanediamine selectivity of 5.8 % and 4.3 %, respectively. This suboptimal performance may be attributed to the strong alkalinity of NaOH, which induces rapid precipitation of metal salts and subsequent agglomeration of metal particles, whereas the weaker alkalinity of ammonia may lead to incomplete precipitation, thereby negatively impacting catalyst performance. Notably, the combined use of NaOH and ammonia improved catalyst performance. When Na₂CO₃ was used as the precipitant, PIP selectivity reached 47.7 %, while the selectivity for 1,5-pentanediamine was 9.9 %. Further improvement was achieved using a NaOH-Na₂CO₃ mixture at a 1:1 molar ratio, resulting in PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine selectivity of 48.3 % and 14.7 %, respectively. This enhancement is likely attributable to the combined formation of hydroxide and carbonate precipitates, which generate metal oxides through distinct mechanisms during calcination and positively influence catalyst performance. Therefore, a 1:1 NaOH-Na₂CO₃ molar ratio was selected as the optimal precipitant composition for metal core preparation, given its ability to balance catalytic performance and product selectivity. The effects of metal salt and precipitant flow rates on catalyst performance were systematically investigated. As shown in Fig. 3 (c), selectivity exhibited a trend of increasing and then decreasing as the flow rate was reduced from 15 mL/min to 5 mL/min, with the highest piperidine (PIP) selectivity of 51.1 % observed at 7.5 mL/min. The selectivity of 1,5-pentane diamine also followed a similar trend, reaching 14.5 % at the same flow rate. TEM analysis revealed that insufficient mixing at higher flow rates caused heterogeneous nucleation, resulting in non-uniform particle sizes and decreased catalyst performance. On the other hand, lower flow rates facilitated particle aggregation due to prolonged residence times, leading to larger average particle sizes and reduced catalytic efficiency. Therefore, a flow rate of 7.5 mL/min was identified as optimal, promoting uniform particle formation and balanced catalytic performance. By optimizing the molar ratio of precipitant to metal salts, the type of precipitant, and the flow rate, the continuous preparation method significantly enhanced the performance of the catalyst. Under the optimal conditions, which include a total metal salt concentration of 0.2 mol/L, a 1:1 molar ratio of Na₂CO₃ and NaOH in the precipitant mixture, a precipitant-to-metal salt molar ratio of 2:1, and equal flow rates of 7.5 mL/min for both the metal salt and precipitant solutions, the L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 catalyst demonstrated superior performance in the reductive amination of 4-CB to piperidine compared to the meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 catalyst (Table S1, entry 26). As a result, L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 was identified as the optimal catalyst for this reaction. 3.3.2 Optimization of reaction conditions Following the identification of the optimal catalyst using the membrane dispersion microreactor, the impact of reaction temperature on selectivity was examined. As shown in Fig. 4 (a), the selectivity for both PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine initially increased with rising temperature, reaching a peak before declining. At 90 °C, the total selectivity for PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine reached a maximum of 53.1 % and 15.9 %, respectively. This trend is attributed to the fact that lower reaction temperatures hinder the hydrogenation of intermediates such as tetrahydropyridine and imine, resulting in reduced selectivity for PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine. Conversely, excessively high temperatures promote side reactions. According to the proposed reaction mechanism depicted in Scheme 3, intermolecular condensation reactions between the intermediate tetrahydropyridine and the product PIP may occur at elevated temperatures, leading to a decline in PIP selectivity. Similarly, 1,5-pentanediamine is prone to polymerization at high temperatures, resulting in the formation of polymers. Based on these observations, 90 °C was selected as the optimal reaction temperature. Reaction time is a critical variable influencing the outcome of many catalytic processes. As illustrated in Fig. 4 (b), the selectivity for PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine increased from 38.0 % and 9.9–55.7 % and 15.2 %, respectively, as the reaction time was extended from 3 to 7 hours. This improvement is attributed to insufficient contact between the catalyst and intermediates at shorter reaction times, which hinders the full hydrogenation of tetrahydropyridine and imine intermediates into PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine. However, when the reaction time was further extended from 7 to 11 hours, the selectivity for PIP decreased steadily. This decline is likely due to prolonged interaction between the catalyst and reactants, which enhances the formation of side products, thus reducing the selectivity for PIP. Therefore, an optimal reaction time of 7 hours was determined. Literature has shown that in the reductive amination of carbonyl compounds, an appropriate amount of ammonia improves substrate conversion and inhibits direct hydrogenation of the carbonyl group to alcohols [31,32]. Consequently, the effect of substrate and ammonia molar ratio was investigated. As shown in Fig. 4 (c), when the substrate and ammonia molar ratio was 1:9, the selectivity for PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine was only 46.3 % and 10.9 %, respectively. This could be due to the tendency of the carbonyl and nitrile groups of 4-CB to undergo hydrogenation at low ammonia ratios, leading to an increased formation of the by-product 5-amino-1-pentanol. As the molar ratio was increased from 1:9–1:11, the selectivity for PIP improved. However, further increasing the molar ratio from 1:11–1:13 resulted in a decrease in PIP selectivity from 59.6 % to 54.9 % and in 1,5-pentanediamine selectivity from 12.4 % to 8.1 %. This reduction is likely due to the excess NH3 irreversibly adsorbing onto the catalyst's metal active sites, thereby inhibiting the coordination of the cyano-functional intermediate to the active sites and hindering the overall reductive amination reaction [33]. Thus, a substrate and ammonia molar ratio of 1:11 was identified as optimal, yielding 59.6 % PIP and 12.4 % 1,5-pentanediamine. With the optimal substrate and ammonia ratio established, the influence of H2 pressure on catalytic performance was subsequently examined. As shown in Fig. 4 (d), increasing the H2 pressure on catalytic performance was subsequently examined. Increasing the H2 pressure from 1.5 MPa to 2.25 MPa resulted in a rise in selectivity for PIP from 50.4 % to 63.8 % and for 1,5-pentanediamine from 10.1 % to 13.8 %, culminating in a total selectivity of 77.6 %. The reason for this phenomenon is that insufficient H2 pressure hinders the hydrogenation of cyano and imine intermediates, resulting in reduced selectivity. However, further increasing the H2 pressure from 2.25 MPa to 2.5 MPa caused a decrease in PIP selectivity from 63.8 % to 56.3 % and in 1,5-pentanediamine selectivity from 13.8 % to 8.8 %. According to the proposed reaction mechanism shown in Scheme 3, this may be due to excessive H2 pressure promoting the hydrogenation of cyano and carbonyl groups, resulting in increased formation of the by-product 5-amino-1-pentanol. Consequently, 2.25 MPa was selected as the optimal H2 pressure. 3.3.3 Lifetime and regeneration of catalyst As shown in Fig. 4 (e), the performance of fresh catalysts decreases significantly after use, with selectivity of only 21.3 % for PIP and 5.4 % for 1,5-pentanediamine. This is due to the fact that some high-boiling substances generated during the reaction process adhered to the surface of the catalysts and formed carbon deposits, which hindered the contact between the reactants and the active center of the catalysts, resulting in the decrease of their catalytic performance. When the used catalyst was regenerated according to the activation conditions (calcination in air at 400 °C for 3 h and reduction in H2 atmosphere at 550 °C for 3 h), its catalytic activity was basically restored to the level of that of the fresh catalyst, with PIP selectivity of 60.1 % and 1,5-pentanediamine selectivity of 11.5 %. This indicates that the regeneration process can remove the carbon deposits and adsorbates on the catalyst surface and re-expose the metal active sites, thus restoring the catalytic performance. Notably, the catalytic activity of the material remained consistently stable even after five consecutive regeneration cycles, as illustrated in Fig. 4 (f), further corroborating the stability of the catalyst. 3.3.4 Pathways for product generation The reaction pathways were inferred based on literature reports and the product distribution observed in the reaction solution, as illustrated in Scheme 3 [12,34,35]. Two primary pathways are proposed for the formation of the main product, PIP: (1) The nitrile group of the substrate 4-CB undergoes hydrogenation catalyzed by the metal nucleus, resulting in the formation of 5-aminopentanal. This intermediate then undergoes dehydration and cyclization to yield tetrahydropyridine, which is further hydrogenated to produce PIP. (2) Alternatively, the carbonyl group of 5-aminopentanal reacts with ammonia to form 5-iminopentan-1-amine. This intermediate undergoes intramolecular nucleophilic addition to generate piperidin-2-amine, which subsequently eliminates a molecule of NH3 to form PIP. 1,5-Pentanediamine can be produced via two pathways: (1) Further hydrogenation of the intermediate 5-iminopentan-1-amine leads to the formation of 1,5-pentanediamine. (2) Alternatively, the carbonyl group of 4-CB reacts with ammonia to produce the intermediate 5-iminopentanenitrile, which is then hydrogenated to yield 5-aminopentanenitrile. Subsequent hydrogenation of the cyano group in 5-aminopentanenitrile generates 1,5-pentanediamine. Additionally, 4-CB's carbonyl group can be hydrogenated to form 5-HPN, which undergoes further hydrogenation to produce 5-amino-1-pentanol. This intermediate is then dehydrated and cyclized to yield valerolactam. In these pathways, all hydrogenation reactions predominantly occur at the active sites of the catalyst's metal core, while the condensation reactions take place at the acidic sites of the shell layer. 3.3.5 Catalyst characterization As Fig. 5 shows the XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts, while Table S11 presents the average particle size of the catalyst samples calculated using the Scherrer equation. As shown in XRD, no distinct NiO diffraction peaks are observed in any of the catalyst samples, indicating that NiO is almost completely reduced to elemental Ni. The catalyst Ni@Al₂O₃-0.2 (a) exhibits characteristic diffraction peaks of metallic Ni (JCPDS 04–8247) at 2θ = 44.61°, 51.90°, and 76.47° corresponding to the (111), (200), and (220) planes, respectively. Upon introducing Co into the catalyst, the diffraction peaks slightly shift to lower angles (2θ = 44.51°, 51.80°, and 76.37°). The crystal size of the Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (b) catalyst decreases from 14.77 nm to 13.46 nm. This change indicates the formation of a nickel-cobalt alloy and the synergistic effect between the metals [21,36,37]. Compared to Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (b), the (111) diffraction peak of the catalyst L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (c) is sharper, indicating that the crystallite size of the nickel-cobalt alloy prepared by the continuous method is smaller than that prepared by the intermittent method, which contributes to improved catalytic performance [38]. This is consistent with the reaction results: for catalyst (b), the selectivity for PIP is 39.2 % and for 1,5-pentanediamine is 15.1 %, while for catalyst (c), the selectivity for PIP and 1,5-pentanediamine are 48.3 % and 14.7 %, respectively. These results demonstrate that the continuous method for preparing this catalyst offers an advantage over the intermittent method and leads to higher selectivity for piperidine. Although the shell layers of all catalyst samples are composed of Al₂O₃, no distinct diffraction peaks corresponding to Al₂O₃ were observed in the XRD spectra, indicating that Al₂O₃ exists in an amorphous form. Furthermore, the diffraction peaks of the spent catalyst (d) remained unchanged, and no new phases were detected, suggesting that the catalyst maintained structural stability during the reaction process. After calcination and reduction, the catalytic performance was fully restored. As shown in Table S11, when the molar ratio of precipitant to metal salts was 2:1, the crystallite size of catalyst (g) was 13.47 nm, which was smaller than the sizes observed at molar ratios of 1.75:1 and 2.25:1. As shown in Fig. 6, the wide-scan XPS spectra of the catalyst samples confirm the presence of elements such as Ni, Co, O, and Al, while carbon (C) originates from the adsorption of CO₂ during catalyst preparation and testing. The high-resolution XPS spectra of the Ni 2p orbital, shown in Fig. 7, reveal spin-orbit coupling, appearing as double peaks at 2p₃/₂ and 2p₁/₂. For the Ni@Al₂O₃-0.2 catalyst (a), the binding energies at 852.38 eV and 855.62 eV are attributed to Ni⁰ 2p₃/₂ and Ni²⁺ 2p₃/₂, respectively. For the bimetallic catalyst Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (b), the binding energies at 852.52 eV and 855.91 eV are similarly attributed to Ni⁰ 2p₃/₂ and Ni²⁺ 2p₃/₂ [12]. The increase in binding energies upon cobalt introduction is due to cobalt's higher electronegativity, which causes electron transfer from nickel to cobalt, raising the average energy of cobalt's d-electrons. This interaction further supports the formation of a Ni-Co alloy and the synergistic effect between the metals [39]. Notably, when the catalyst L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (c) was prepared using the continuous method, the binding energies of Ni⁰ 2p₃/₂ and Ni²⁺ 2p₃/₂ increased to 852.57 eV and 855.98 eV, respectively, compared to the catalyst prepared by the intermittent method, Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (b). The binding energy for Co@Al₂O₃-0.2 (d) was 778.9 eV, attributed to Co²⁺ 2p₃/₂, while the Co²⁺ 2p₃/₂ binding energy for Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (e) slightly decreased to 778.3 eV, further indicating the electron interaction between nickel and cobalt. The Ni⁰ 2p₃/₂ binding energies for the used (f) and regenerated (g) L7.5-meso-Ni₇Co₃@Al₂O₃-0.2 catalysts did not change significantly, demonstrating good stability of the catalyst. From Fig. 7 and Table 1, it is evident that the Ni⁰ 2p₃/₂ peak area for the used catalyst significantly decreased, and the surface carbon content increased, indicating carbon deposition on the catalyst surface. After calcination, reduction, and regeneration, the catalytic performance was fully restored, with an increase in the Ni⁰ 2p₃/₂ peak area and a decrease in the surface carbon content. Additionally, all catalyst samples exhibited a Ni²⁺ 2p₃/₂ main peak around 855.9 eV, with a satellite peak appearing between 861.21 and 861.82 eV indicating that some Ni²⁺ could be reduced to Ni⁰. Fig. 8 shows the N₂ adsorption-desorption isotherms (Ⅰ, Ⅱ) and pore size distribution (Ⅲ, Ⅳ) of the reduced catalyst samples, while Table 2 presents the specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size data of the catalysts. As shown in Fig. 8 (Ⅰ, Ⅱ), all catalyst samples exhibit an IV-type isotherm and an H3-type hysteresis loop, indicating the presence of a significant amount of mesoporous structures in the catalysts [40,41]. From the pore size distribution (Ⅲ, Ⅳ), it is evident that the pores in the catalysts are primarily distributed between 2 and 40 nm, consistent with the characteristics of typical mesoporous structures. According to Table 2, the specific surface area of the Ni7Co3 metal core is 3.58 m²/g, and after the formation of pores on the metal core, the specific surface area increases to 5.29 m²/g, an increase of approximately 1.5 times. Catalytic experiments show that the catalyst Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (with Ni7Co3 as the metal core) achieves 100 % conversion of 4-CB, with a selectivity of 39.2 % for PIP and 15.1 % for glutaraldehyde. In contrast, the catalyst meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (with meso-Ni7Co3 as the metal core) also achieves 100 % conversion of 4-CB, but with an improved selectivity of 48.7 % for PIP and 18.9 % for glutaraldehyde. These results clearly demonstrate that forming pores on the metal core can effectively increase the catalyst pores on the metal core can effectively increase the catalyst's specific surface area, thereby enhancing its catalytic performance. Additionally, as shown in Table 2, compared to the uncoated catalyst (b), the coated catalyst (c) shows a significant increase in specific surface area, indicating that the Al₂O₃ shell effectively enhances the surface area of the catalyst. The structural data of the fresh catalyst (c), used catalyst (d), and regenerated catalyst (e) in Table 2 show a decrease in specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size after use. This change is attributed to the formation of carbon deposits on the catalyst surface during the reaction, which covers the active sites and reduces catalytic performance. However, after calcination and reduction, these properties are partially restored, indicating that high-temperature calcination effectively removes the carbon deposits, re-exposing the active sites and restoring catalytic activity. According to the literature, appropriate acidic sites can promote the adsorption of substrates, ammonia, and intermediates, thereby enhancing the reductive amination of carbonyl compounds [42]. The acidity of the catalyst surfaces was determined using NH₃-TPD. As shown in Fig. 9, three ammonia desorption peaks were observed between 100 and 700 °C for the reduced catalysts, corresponding to weak acid sites (150–200 °C), medium-strength acid sites (250–450 °C), and strong acid sites (550–750 °C) [43]. Table 3 shows that while the acidity strengths of Ni7Co3@SiO₂-0.2 and Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 are similar, Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 contains more acidic sites. The large number of acidic sites provided by the Al₂O₃ shell may account for the higher PIP yield (39.2 %) of Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 compared to Ni7Co3@SiO₂-0.2 (31.0 %). These sites enhance the adsorption, condensation, and dehydration of intermediates and ammonia, which positively impacts the overall catalytic reaction. To analyze the reducibility of the catalyst samples and the interaction between Ni and Co metals, H₂-TPR experiments were conducted, and the results are shown in Fig. 10. For catalyst (a), a reduction peak at 404 °C corresponds to the reduction of nickel oxide, with no additional low-temperature peaks observed. Upon the introduction of cobalt, the primary reduction peak of catalyst (b) shifted to a lower temperature, and a new low-temperature reduction peak appeared. This shift may be attributed to the formation of NiCo₂O₄ spinel in the catalyst precursor due to the addition of cobalt, which enhances the reducibility of the catalyst [44]. The emergence of the low-temperature reduction peak is associated with the presence of NiO, Co₃O₄, and NiCo₂O₄ spinels in the bimetallic precursor, all of which exhibit similar reducibility [45]. As the cobalt content increases, the reduction peaks for catalysts (c) and (d) continue to shift to lower temperatures, with the low-temperature peaks intensifying. This further confirms the formation of the Ni-Co alloy, which is consistent with the results from XRD and XPS analyses [46]. To further explore and confirm these findings, the morphology and metal core dispersion of the reduced catalyst samples were characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), as shown in Fig. 11. For catalyst Ni@Al₂O₃-0.2 (a), the metal particle size ranged from 12 to 16 nm, with an average size of 14.73 nm, which is consistent with the particle size calculated from XRD spectra. TEM analysis of catalyst Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (b) revealed that the introduction of Co as the second metal reduced the metal particle size to 10–16 nm, with an average size of 13.5 nm. This reduction in particle size may be attributed to improved metal dispersion resulting from Co incorporation, which aligns with the XRD results. For catalyst meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (c), TEM images showed small pores on the metal core, with particle sizes ranging from 9 to 16 nm and an average size of 12.8 nm, indicating successful pore formation on the metal core. As shown in Fig. 11 (d), the metal core prepared via the continuous method had an average particle size of 11.02 nm, significantly smaller than that of the core prepared by the intermittent method. Moreover, the catalyst prepared by the continuous method exhibited a more uniform particle size distribution. The HRTEM image of catalyst L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (d), presented in Fig. 11 (i), showed a lattice spacing of 0.215 nm, consistent with the Ni-Co (111) lattice spacing reported in the literature [47]. This confirms the formation of the Ni-Co alloy phase, in agreement with the XRD, XPS, and H₂-TPR results, further demonstrating the synergistic catalytic effect between Ni and Co. Additionally, the HRTEM image revealed that the Ni-Co metal core was encapsulated within the Al₂O₃ shell, forming a distinct core-shell structure. Elemental mapping in Fig. 12 further illustrated the uniform distribution of Ni, Co, O, and Al in catalyst (d). For catalyst L5.0-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (g), TEM images showed that reducing the flow rate of metal salt and precipitant from 7.5 mL/min to 5.0 mL/min increased the average particle size from 11.02 nm to 15.09 nm. This indicates that a slower flow rate promotes particle aggregation, leading to larger particle sizes. Conversely, increasing the flow rate to 10 mL/min resulted in an average particle size of 13.70 nm for catalyst L10.0-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2 (h), with less uniform size distribution, possibly due to inadequate mixing of the metal salt and precipitant at higher flow rates. TEM images of the used catalyst (e) revealed a blurred surface and an increase in average particle size from 11.02 nm to 14.2 nm, caused by metal core aggregation and carbon deposition during the reaction. The regenerated catalyst (f) showed clear metal core dispersion in the TEM images, indicating that carbon deposits had been effectively removed. However, the average particle size of the re-generated catalyst was slightly larger than that of the fresh catalyst, which may explain the incomplete recovery of catalytic performance after regeneration. 4 Conclusions This study introduces a green and innovative strategy for synthesizing piperidine (PIP) from biomass-derived δ-valerolactone through a multi-step process involving catalytic amination, oxidation, and reductive amination. The catalytic amination of δ-valerolactone to 5-HPN achieved a remarkable conversion of 94.0 % and a selectivity of 75.54 % under optimized conditions. Subsequently, the oxidation of 5-HPN utilizing the Anelli catalytic system yielded 4-cyanobutanal (4-CB) with a 99 % conversion rate and an excellent yield of 93.7 %. The reductive amination of 4-CB to PIP was performed using the bimetallic core-shell catalyst L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2, which was synthesized through a continuous method in a membrane dispersion microreactor. Under ideal conditions, this process ensured the complete conversion of 4-CB, yielding a PIP selectivity of 63.8 % and an overall selectivity of 88.4 %. The catalysts were rigorously characterized through XRD, XPS, N₂ adsorption-desorption, H₂-TPR, NH₃-TPD, and TEM analyses. Results revealed that nickel and cobalt existed as homogeneously dispersed Ni-Co alloys encapsulated within an Al₂O₃ shell. This structure enhanced the specific surface area and provided abundant acidic sites, facilitating intermediate adsorption, condensation, and dehydration. Furthermore, the porous structure of the metal core contributed to an increased surface area, further boosting the catalytic activity. The synthesis process in the membrane dispersion system demonstrated that the precipitant-to-metal salt ratio and reactant flow rates were critical factors influencing the particle size of the catalyst. Although carbon deposition was identified as the primary cause of catalyst deactivation, high-temperature calcination effectively regenerated the catalyst, while minimal metal particle aggregation ensured that its catalytic performance remained largely intact after regeneration. coredata.dc:description: Piperidine (PIP) is an important nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compound used extensively in pharmaceuticals, agrochemicals, and rubber additives. Conventional synthesis routes often require energy-intensive conditions or noble metal catalysts, posing environmental and economic challenges. This work presents a sustainable chemical process for PIP production, starting from biomass-derived δ-valerolactone. The key reductive amination step employs a bimetallic Ni-Co core-shell catalyst (L7.5-meso-Ni7Co3@Al₂O₃-0.2), prepared via a continuous-flow method. Under optimized conditions, a 100 % conversion of 4-cyanobutanal (4-CB) was achieved with 63.8 % selectivity for PIP. Catalyst synergy between Ni and Co enhanced activity while reducing reliance on noble metals. This study demonstrates a scalable strategy for sustainable PIP production, aligning with green chemistry principles by employing renewable feedstocks, minimizing waste, and achieving high efficiency under mild conditions.
